application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Possibility Distribution-Based Approach for MAGDM With Hesitant Fuzzy Linguistic Information
div.p: Zhibin Wu, Member, IEEE, and Jiuping Xu, Senior Member, IEEE Abstract-In group decision making (GDM) with qualitative settings, experts may require several possible linguistic values rather than a single term to express their preferences. A hesitant fuzzy linguistic term set has recently been developed to manage this situation. In line with this development, in this paper, we present a new framework model to address multiple attribute GDM with hesitant fuzzy linguistic information. First, the concept of a possibility distribution is defined. Based on the possibility distributions, some aggregation operators such as the hesitant fuzzy linguistic weighted average operator and the hesitant fuzzy linguistic ordered weighted average operator are proposed. A consensus measure is then defined and a consensus reaching process is given which uses different identification and direction rules compared with the existing methods. A selection process is also described to rank the alternatives. Both processes are necessary to support stakeholders when making rational decisions. Finally, two simulated examples are given to verify the practicability of the proposed approach.
Index Terms-Aggregation operator, consensus process, hesitant fuzzy linguistic term set (HFLTS), possibility distribution, selection process.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: I N REAL decision situations, the experts, characterized by their background and knowledge, express their ideas using linguistic descriptors. In order to deal with the uncertainty concerns regarding the expert subjective assessments, many decision-making models based on linguistic approaches have been developed such as the linguistic twotuple model [21], the proportional two-tuple model [46], the numerical scale [11], [13], [14], the linguistic computational model based on discrete fuzzy numbers [30], granular computing [57], and the type-2 fuzzy sets based model [5], [32], [33]. Each of these models has been successful in addressing one particular kind of problem. For example, the two-tuple linguistic model has been widely used because of its accuracy and usefulness in improving the solution process and understanding the results of such processes [29]. In the above models, experts provide a single term or interval value to express their preferences. However, in some cases, experts may have a set of possible values about the attributes or alternatives. Hesitant fuzzy sets (HFSs), whose membership functions are represented by a set of possible values, are, therefore, better at handling these new cases.

Torra [45] initiated the notable concept of the HFS, which represented a new generalization for fuzzy sets, as this method permits an element to have not just one but a set of several possible membership values. As a result of this innovation, the HFS has attracted increasing attention from the academic world since its introduction [25], [49]- [51], [63], [64]. Rodríguez et al. [41] provided a good review on HFS. However, it has been observed that both fuzzy linguistic and HFS-based approaches are limited when dealing with situations, in which the experts have several possible linguistic values or richer expressions than a single term for an indicator, alternative, or variable. By combining the merits of the HFS and linguistic terms, Rodríguez et al. [40] further proposed the concept of the hesitant fuzzy linguistic term set (HFLTS). This new approach, based on the fuzzy linguistic approach and the use of context-free grammars, increased the flexibility and richness of linguistic elicitation.

Following the pioneering work of Rodríguez et al. [40], HFLTSs have drawn a lot of interest from different points of view. Beg and Rashid [3] extended the technique for order preference by similarity to an ideal solution (TOPSIS) method for HFLTS. Liu and Rodríguez [28] presented a new representation of the HFLTSs by means of a fuzzy envelope to carry out the computing with word processes. Zhu and Xu [63] developed a hesitant fuzzy linguistic preference relation (HFLPR) concept and studied its consistency measures. Zhang and Wu [61] defined the multiplicative consistency property of HFLPRs and gave a characterization of multiplicative consistency for HFLPRs. Liao et al. [26] discussed distance and similarity measures for the HFLTS. Wei et al. [48] noted the unreasonable case of the comparison method for HFLTS presented in [40] and gave possibility degree formulas for comparing HFLTSs.

The key task of the decision-making approaches of HFLTSs is how to make the best use of the information represented by HFLTSs. The method in [63] requires that the HFLTSs concerned must have the same length to carry out the computations correctly. However, in many cases, the number of values of different HFLTSs are different. Therefore, in such a method, some normalization method is necessary and the information may be distorted. The envelope method in [9] and [28] aggregated linguistic terms in an HFLTS into a trapezoidal fuzzy set. The envelop method needs an approximate process to realize the transformation from HFLTS to fuzzy set. As there is currently no easy way to deal with the HFLTS, the search for new ways that maintain the simplicity of the current models is still ongoing. In addition, to solve the multiple attribute group decision making (MAGDM) problems with HFLTSs, both consensus and selection processes are worth of being generalized as they are the two essential parts of any group decision making (GDM) problem. Since the consensus and selection processes of MAGDM problems with HFLTSs have not been discussed, we also explore these two processes under HFLTSs. Considering the above motivations, we first present the idea of a possibility distribution for an HFLTS. Importantly, the proposed approach provides a natural explanation for the linguistic terms in an HFLTS since HFLTS is originally presented to manage the possible linguistic values. We then develop corresponding operation laws and aggregation operators and build a framework to deal with both consensus and selection processes for MAGDM problems with HFLTSs.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we briefly introduce the HFLTS concepts. In Section III, we define the concept of possibility distribution and present some aggregation operators to manage the HFLTS fusion. In Section IV, we present a consensus reaching process. In Section V, we deal with the selection process. In Section VI, we illustrate the proposed decision-making framework model and make a comparative study by examples. In Section VII, we discuss the characteristics and the potential extensions of the proposed approach. Finally, in Section VIII, we conclude this paper.

div.head: II. PRELIMINARIES
div.p: In this section, the basic concepts of HFLTS are briefly reviewed and highlighted.

The fuzzy linguistic approach and other different linguistic extensions are based on the elicitation of simple terms that encompass and express the information provided by the experts using a linguistic variable. However, similar to the situations that are described and managed by the HFS in [45], where an expert may consider several values to define a membership function, in the qualitative setting experts may hesitate between several values when assessing a linguistic variable. At present, the fuzzy linguistic approach is very limited when dealing with these situations. To overcome such limitations, Rodríguez et al. [40] proposed the concept of HFLTS to increase the richness and flexibility of linguistic information elicitation using linguistic expressions.
Definition 1 [40]: Let S = {s 0 , . . . , s g } be a linguistic term set, then an HFLTS, H S , is an ordered finite subset of the consecutive linguistic terms of S.

Based on the above definition, the empty HFLTS and the full HFLTS for a linguistic variable ϑ are defined by H S (ϑ) = ∅ and H S (ϑ) = S, respectively. Some HFLTSs based on S might be H S (ϑ 1 ) = {s 1 , s 2 , s 3 }, H S (ϑ 2 ) = {s 5 }, and H S (ϑ 3 ) = {s 5 , s 6 }.
Similar to the HFS, we can define the basic computations and operations using an HFLTS as per the following.

Definition 2 [40]: Let S = {s 0 , . . . , s g } be a linguistic term set. Given three HFLTSs: H S , H 1 S , and H 2 S , the lower and upper bounds, complement, union, and intersection of the HFLTSs are computed as follows.
1) H - S = min{s i } = s j , s i ∈ H S , and
div.formula: s i ≥ s j , ∀i. 2) H + S = max{s i } = s j , s i ∈ H S ,and
s i ≤ s j , ∀i. 3) H c S = S -H S = {s i |s i ∈ S and s i ∈ H S }. 4) H 1 S ∪ H 2 S = {s i |s i ∈ H 1 S or s i ∈ H 2 S }. 5) H 1 S ∩ H 2 S = {s i |s i ∈ H 1 S and s i ∈ H 2 S }.
div.p: For the sake of convenience, the family of all the HFLTSs defined on S are denoted by HFLTS(S). A simple contextfree grammar G H and a corresponding transformation function were presented by Rodríguez et al. [40] to support the elicitation of linguistic information by experts in hesitant situations. In the sequel, it is supposed that all the initial linguistic expressions are transformed into HFLTS.

div.head: III. POSSIBILITY DISTRIBUTION-BASED APPROACH
div.p: In this section, we first introduce the concept of the possibility distribution for HFLTS. Next, we present some aggregation operators to manage the fusion over HFLTS.

Suppose there are n(n ≥ 2) potential alternatives denoted by A = {A 1 , A 2 , . . . , A n }. Each alternative is evaluated with respect to a predefined attribute set C = {C 1 , C 2 , . . . , C m } (m ≥ 2). There are t experts, = {e 1 , e 2 , . . . , e t }(t ≥ 2). Assume λ = (λ 1 , λ 2 , . . . , λ t ) is the weight vector of the experts, where λ k ∈ (0, 1), k = 1, 2, . . . , t, t k=1 λ k = 1. Suppose that each expert utilizes linguistic variable to express their preferences for the alternatives from a predefined linguistic term set S. However, the experts may be hesitant about the several possible values to evaluate an alternative and therefore each of the attribute values are formulated as an HFLTS. Let R k = (r k ij ) n×m be a hesitant fuzzy linguistic decision matrix given by an expert e k ∈ , where r k ij ∈ HFLTS(S) represents the performance of the alternative A i over the attribute C j ∈ C. The problem in this paper is concerned with the ranking of the alternatives or the selection of the most desirable alternative(s) using the linguistic decision matrices R k , k = 1, 2, . . . , t.

div.head: A. Possibility Distribution for HFLTS
div.p: Let S = {s 0 , . . . , s g } be a predefined linguistic term set. Let L and U be two integers where L, U ∈ {0, 1, . . . , g} and L ≤ U. An HFLTS is denoted by ϑ = {s L , s L+1 , . . . , s U } where s L and s U are the lower and upper bounds of ϑ, respectively. Note that ϑ is a discrete set on S. With the linguistic terms given in this way, the bigger L or U is, the better the corresponding alternative. Without additional information, each linguistic term s k in the HFLTS ϑ is supposed to have an equal possibility to be the expert's assessment value. That is, the expert at this time has no further preference for the linguistic variables that they have shown hesitation toward. Since there are U -L + 1 linguistic terms in ϑ, ϑ is thought to be uniformly distributed on {s L , s L+1 , . . . , s U }. Furthermore, ϑ can be considered to have a possibility distribution across the entire linguistic term set S.

Definition 3: Let S = {s 0 , . . . , s g }. Let ϑ = {s L , s L+1 , . . . , s U } be an HFLTS given by an expert. The possibility distribution for ϑ on S is represented by P = ( p 0 , p 1 , . . . , p l , . . . , p g ), where p l is given by
and p l denotes the possibility that the alternative has an assessment value s l provided by the expert such that g l=0 p l = 1 and 0 ≤ p l ≤ 1, l = 0, 1, . . . , g.
A special case is that the expert has a certain preference and gives only one linguistic term as the assessment value. In this case, (1) is given by

Different HFLTSs defined on the same S differ at their respective possibility distributions. In probability theory, ϑ is viewed as a discrete random variable and the corresponding possibility distribution P is viewed as a probability mass function. At the beginning, the expert has an equal possibility to employ the linguistic terms in ϑ to evaluate the alternatives. However, after interaction with other experts in the decisionmaking process, both elements in ϑ and possibility distribution may change.

Example 2: Let S = {s 0 , . . . , s 8 }. ϑ 1 = {s 1 , s 2 } represents that the expert gives a probability 0.5 for s 1 and a probability 0.5 for s 2 , respectively. ϑ 2 = {s 4 , s 5 , s 6 } then indicates that the expert gives a probability of 1/3 for s 4 , s 5 , and s 6 , respectively. The possibility distributions corresponding to ϑ 1 and ϑ 2 are p 1 = (0, 1/2, 1/2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0) and p 2 = (0, 0, 0, 0, 1/3, 1/3, 1/3, 0, 0), respectively.

Remark 1: Fan and Liu [16] and Fan et al. [17] proposed probability-based approach to deal with the ordinal interval numbers. Zhang et al. [59] proposed a concept of distribution assessment in a linguistic term set. The background in [16], [17], and [59] are quite different from that in this paper. Let S = {s -2 = very poor, s -1 = poor, s 0 = average, s 1 = good, s 2 = very good}. Consider a football coach evaluating the performance of a player in the past ten games. If the coach gave s 2 five times, s 1 two times, and s -1 three times, then the distribution assessment {(s -2 , 0), (s -1 , 0.3), (s 0 , 0), (s 1 , 0.2), (s 2 , 0.5)} can be used to describe this situation. Inspired by the pioneer researches as in [16], [40], and [59], we develop this new way to deal with HFLTS.
To present the computational technique needed to operate the possibility distributions, the expectation and variance of possibility distributions are defined.

Definition 4: Let S = {s 0 , . . . , s g } and ϑ ∈ HFLTS(S). The possibility distribution corresponding to ϑ is P = ( p 0 , p 1 , . . . , p l , . . . , p g ). Then, the mean (or expected value) for ϑ indicated by P can be defined as follows:
div.formula: E(ϑ) = g l=0 NS(s l )p l (3)
div.p: where NS(s l ) is the numerical scale of s l . The numerical scale establishes a one-to-one mapping between the linguistic information and the numerical values [11]. However, to date, there is no easy way to derive a suitable numerical scale NS for a given linguistic term set S. If S is a uniformly and symmetrically distributed linguistic term set, we have NS(s l ) = l.
Definition 5: Let S, ϑ, and P be as before. Then, the variance for ϑ indicated by P can be defined as follows:
div.formula: Var(ϑ) = g l=0 (NS(s l ) -E(ϑ)) 2 p l (4
div.p: where NS(s l ) is the numerical scale for s l .
The comparison of the HFLTSs represented by possibility distributions is conducted according to an ordinary lexicographic order.
Definition 6: Suppose two HFLTSs ϑ 1 , ϑ 2 ∈ HFLTS(S), so the comparison operation over ϑ 1 and ϑ 2 can be defined as follows.
div.formula: ) If E(ϑ 1 ) < E(ϑ 2 ), then ϑ 1 < ϑ 2 , max{ϑ 1 , ϑ 2 } = ϑ 2 and min{ϑ 1 , ϑ 2 } = ϑ 1 . 2) If E(ϑ 1 ) = E(ϑ 2 ), then: a) if Var(ϑ 1 ) < Var(ϑ 2 ), then ϑ 1 > ϑ 2 ; b) if Var(ϑ 1 ) = Var(ϑ 2 ), then ϑ 1 = ϑ 2 .
div.p: If two possibility distributions have the same mean and variance, then they are also the same.

div.head: B. Aggregation Operators
div.p: This section is devoted to the development of some aggregation operators for the integration of the HFLTSs based on their possibility distributions. The desirable properties for the developed aggregation operators are then given.
Definition 7: Let H θ = {ϑ 1 , . . . , ϑ n } be a set of HFLTSs, where ϑ k ∈ HFLTS(S) and W = {w 1 , . . . , w n } are their associated weights such that 0 ≤ w i ≤ 1 and
div.formula: n k=1 w k = 1. Each ϑ k is transformed to a possibility distribution P k = ( p k 0 , . . . , p k l , . . . , p k g ).
div.p: The hesitant fuzzy linguistic weighted average (HFLWA) operator is also defined as a possibility distribution P = ( p 0 , . . . , p l , . . . , p g ) HFLWA(ϑ 1 , . . . , ϑ n ) = HFLWA P 1 , . . . , P n = p 0 , . . . , p l , . . . , p g (5) where p l is computed by
div.formula: p l = n k=1 w k p k l . (6
div.p: Definition 8: Let H θ , W, and P k be as before. The hesitant fuzzy linguistic ordered weighted average (HFLOWA) operator is also defined as a possibility distribution P = ( p 0 , . . . , p l , . . . , p g ) HFLOWA(ϑ 1 , . . . , ϑ n ) = HFLOWA P 1 , . . . , P n = p 0 , . . . , p l , . . . , p g (7) where p l is computed by
div.formula: p l = n k=1 w k p σ (k) l (8)
div.p: and
div.formula: {σ (1), . . . , σ (n)} is a permutation of {1, 2, . . . , n} such that ϑ σ (i) ≥ ϑ σ (j) if i ≥ j.
div.p: Note that the aggregated possibility distribution does not in general have a uniform distribution over S but a special discrete distribution over S. However, this is an overall preference value derived from set H θ .

The properties of the HFLWA and HFLOWA operators are verified in the following. The HFLWA operator satisfies monotonicity, idempotency, and boundedness. The HFLOWA operator satisfies monotonicity, idempotency, boundedness, and commutativity. Please see Appendix A of the supplementary material for the proofs of these properties.

div.head: IV. CONSENSUS PROCESS
div.p: A fundamental aspect of GDM is the importance of looking for approaches to reach consensus, a focus which has attracted a great deal of attention and has become a major research topic in the GDM field. Consensus can be understood in various ways and in various contexts in GDM [8]. For example, it may refer to the multiple criteria approach, the model, the tools, the procedures or the way that the collective judgments are used to derive the final group preferences [1]. In this paper, consensus refers to the manner in which the group members achieve a minimum level of agreement on the group decision matrix. A large number of approaches have been developed to support the modeling for consensus reaching processes [2], [10], [15], [22], [24], [27], [31], [34]- [36], [39], [44]. Cabrerizo et al. [7] and Herrera-Viedma et al. [23] presented an excellent overview of consensus models based on soft consensus measures in a fuzzy environment.

From the literature, there have been a few papers which have focused on consensus models in an MAGDM setting [18], [37], [38], [42], [53]. However, these models are not suitable for dealing with the consensus process under a hesitant fuzzy linguistic setting. In the following, we define the consensus measures between two hesitant fuzzy linguistic decision matrices and develop a procedure to reach a consensus in an MAGDM with hesitant fuzzy linguistic information.

div.head: A. Consensus Measure
div.p: There are two categories for computing consensus measures based on the: 1) distance to the collective preference and 2) distance between the experts [35]. This paper follows the latter definition for the consensus measure.
First, by measuring the distance between two HFLTSs, we have the following definition.

Definition 9: Suppose two HFLTSs ϑ, η ∈ HFLTS(S), and their corresponding possibility distributions are denoted as P = ( p 0 , . . . , p l , . . . , p g ) and Q = (q 0 , . . . , q l , . . . , q g ), respectively. The similarity degree between these two preference values can be defined as
div.formula: sd(ϑ, η) = sd(P, Q) = 1 - 1 g g l=0 NS(s l )p l - g l=0 NS(s l )q l (9)
div.p: where NS(s l ) is the numerical scale for s l . Obviously, 0 ≤ sd(ϑ, η) ≤ 1. The closer sd(ϑ, η) is to 1, the more similar ϑ and η, while the closer sd(ϑ, η) is to 0, the more distant ϑ and η. The level of agreement between experts can be computed in the following steps.
1) For each pair of experts e l and e k , a similarity matrix SM lk = (sm lk ij ) n×m can be defined by
where sm lk ij is the similarity degree between experts e l and e k in their assessments for the alterative A i over the attribute C j , i = 1, 2, . . . , n, j = 1, 2, . . . , m. That is
div.formula: sm lk ij = sd r l ij , r k ij = 1 - 1 g g h=0 NS(s l )p l ij,h - g h=0 NS(s l )p k ij,h(11)
div.p: where P l ij = ( p l ij,0 , . . . , p l ij,g ) and P k ij = ( p k ij,0 , . . . , p k ij,g ) are the possibility distributions for r l ij and r k ij , respectively.

2) A consensus matrix CM = (cm ij ) n×m is computed by aggregating all the similarity matrices associated with each pair of experts (e l , e k ). There are (t(t -1)/2) similarity matrices. The aggregation is carried out by an aggregation operator, Agg
If the arithmetic average operator is implemented
div.formula: cm ij = t-1 l=1 t k=l+1 sm lk ij t(t -1)/2 . (13
div.p: 3) Once the consensus matrix CM is computed, we can then determine the consensus degrees. As mentioned, inspired by Herrera-Viedma et al.'s [22] approach, the consensus degrees are explored on the following three levels. a) Attribute Level: The consensus degree for an alternative A i over an attribute C j , denoted as cc ij , is defined to measure the consensus level amongst all the experts on that alternative over the given attribute. In this case, it can be expressed using the element from the collective similarity matrix CM

The closer cc ij is to 1, the greater the agreement amongst all experts on the alternative A i over the attribute C j . This measure is used to identify those positions in the decision matrix which have a poor consensus level. b) Alternatives Level: The consensus degree on an alternative A i , called ca i , is defined to measure the consensus level amongst all experts for that alternative
div.formula: ca i = m j=1 cc ij m . (15
div.p: This measure allows for the identification of those alternatives lower than the threshold. c) Decision Matrix Level: The consensus degree on the decision matrix, called cd, is defined to measure the global consensus level amongst the experts' preferences and is used to control the progress of the consensus reaching process. It is computed as
div.formula: cd = min i {ca i }.(16)
div.p: Although the overall consensus degree cd can be calculated using the arithmetic mean of all the consensus degrees on the alternatives, we chose the min operator to allow for a more rigorous criterion. In this way, the compromise between some alternatives with very high consensus levels and those with very low consensus levels is avoided.

div.head: B. Consensus Reaching Process
div.p: Once the consensus degrees for the different levels are obtained, a comparison between the actual consensus level and the consensus threshold γ ∈ [0, 1] defined a priori is conducted. If cd ≥ γ , then the consensus reaching process ends; otherwise a new interaction should be conducted. The value of γ depends on the particular problem to be solved and provides a flexible choice for the group to control the progress of the decision process. However, this value has to be carefully chosen to avoid the need for too many alterations. A survey of the literature showed that these parameters are often subjectively determined by the experts in the group [15], [22], [36], [59].

In Herrera-Viedma et al.'s [22] method, the feedback mechanism used proximity measures to identify those experts furthest away from the collective opinion. This kind of method has two steps: 1) a computation of the proximity measures and 2) a production of the advice. The proximity measures evaluate the agreement between the individual preferences and the group preferences. Note that in [6], [12], [37], and [52], the proximity measures in [22] are just the consensus measures which are directly used to guide the feedback system. The second step is to generate recommendations or advices for the experts to achieve a solution which has the highest degree of consensus possible. This second step consists of two types of advice rules: 1) identification rules (IRs) and 2) direction rules (DRs). Different to the method presented in [22], in our proposed feedback mechanism, we do not use proximity measures but build the advice production directly on the consensus measures developed in Section IV-A. The proposed consensus reaching process for an MAGDM problem with hesitant fuzzy linguistic information is depicted as a flowchart in Fig. 1.

1) IR: These rules are utilized to identify the alternatives, the alternative over the attributes and the experts that contribute less to reach a high consensus level. Bearing this in mind, we define a three-step procedure. a) IR for Alternatives (IR.1): Let ALT be the set of alternatives with the associated consensus degree ca i lower than the specified consensus threshold γ . The IR for the alternatives is expressed as

This rule identifies which row of the decision matrix should be modified. The alternatives in ALT have different priorities according to the values for ca i . The smaller the ca i is, the bigger the chance that the preferences for A i should change. In particular, if we want to change only one row each time, the set ALT could be replaced by
div.formula: ALT = A i | min i {ca i } . (18

div.head: b) IR for Attributes of the Identified Alternatives (IR.2):
div.p: For any alternative A i ∈ ALT, this rule identifies the attributes that the associated assessments for these attributes should change. To do this, the set of attributes for A i , called ATT i , is defined by
div.formula: ATT i = C j |A i ∈ ALT ∧ cc ij < γ . (19
div.p: This rule identifies which column of the decision matrix should be modified for the given rows indented in IR.1. Based on IR.1 and IR.2, the positions that should change are determined. Let the ordered binary pair (i, j) denote a position for the alternative A i over the attribute C j . Then, all the positions in which the assessments should change is given by
div.formula: Pos = {(i, j)|A i ∈ ALT ∧ C j ∈ ATT i }.(20)
div.p: c) IR for Experts (IR.3): This identifies the set of experts that need to receive advice on how to modify their preference values for each element of Pos. The set of experts, called EXPS ij , that should change their preferences are those whose preferences are the most distant from all the other expert preferences at position (i, j). In this case, the distance between expert e l and all other experts e k , k = l is calculated by
div.formula: d l ij = t k=1,k =l 1 -sd r l ij , r k ij = t -1 - t k=1,k =l sm lk ij . (21
div.p: Therefore, EXPS ij can be computed by
div.formula: EXPS ij = e l (i, j) ∈ Pos ∧ d l ij = max k d k ij .(22)
div.p: By combining rules IR.1-IR.3, we know which experts need to change their preferences and where the right place to change is. For example, if e l ∈ EXPS ij , then expert e l should change their preference r l ij . All these elements are further denoted as the set of triples
div.formula: IDF = (l, (i, j)) | e l ∈ EXPS ij ∧ (i, j) ∈ Pos . (23
div.p: 2) DR: This rule is applied to suggest the direction of the changes to the experts to increase the consensus level in the next round. To do this, a group preference for the position (i, j) has to be computed. The group preferences are considered reference target for the experts. The group preference r c ij is obtained using the HFLWA operator. Let the possibility distribution of r c ij be
div.formula: P c ij = ( p c ij,0 , . . . , p c ij,l , . . . , p c ij,g ) HFLWA r 1 ij , . . . , r t ij = p c ij,0 , . . . , p c ij,l , . . . , p c ij,g(24)
div.p: where p c ij,l is computed by
div.formula: p c ij,l = t k=1 λ k p k ij,l . (25
div.p: Based on r c ij , for (l, (i, j)) ∈ IDF, the following DRs are designed. a) DR.1: If r k ij < r c ij , then expert e k should increase their assessment on the alternative A i over the attribute C j . b) DR.2: If r k ij > r c ij , then expert e k should decrease their assessment on the alternative A i over the attribute C j . c) DR.3: If r k ij = r c ij , then expert e k does not need to modify their assessment on the alternative A i over the attribute C j . Note that the comparison between r k ij and r c ij is implemented using Definition 6. If an iterative and a discrete case are taken into account, the experts need to change their preferences by proving the HFLTSs which belong to the original linguistic term set. If an expert wants to continuously adjust their preferences, then the change occurs only on the possibility distribution but not on the original HFLTS. In the latter case, we can build a consensus process that is automatically executed.

div.head: V. SELECTION PROCESS
div.p: We consider an indirect approach, where the solution is on the basis of the collective decision matrix. Once the consensus reaching process is achieved, a collective decision matrix is derived based on the acceptable consensus individual decision matrix. The selection process refers to obtain a solution set of alternatives from the collective decision matrix. The selection process is carried out in two phases [19]: 1) an aggregation phase and 2) an exploitation phrase. The aggregation phase is completed using aggregation operators and the exploitation phrase is completed using choice functions [19], [20], [43].

For the case in this paper, the aggregation phase refers to aggrege the individual hesitant fuzzy linguistic decision matrix into a group hesitant fuzzy linguistic decision matrix. The exploitation phase is conducted to obtain a rank order among the alternatives. In both phases, different aggregation operators can be used.

The notations are described in the second paragraph of Section III. Suppose that after implementing the consensus reaching process, the individual hesitant fuzzy linguistic decision matrix is still denoted by
div.formula: R k = (r k ij ) n×m . Let R c = (r c ij
div.p: ) n×m be the group hesitant fuzzy linguistic decision matrix. P k ij = ( p k ij,0 , . . . , p k ij,g ) and P c ij = ( p c ij,0 , . . . , p c ij,g ) are the possibility distributions corresponding to r k ij and r c ij , respectively. Then, each element r c ij is obtained using the HFLWA operator as follows:
div.formula: HFLWA r 1 ij , . . . , r t ij = HFLWA P 1 ij , . . . , P t ij = p c ij,0 , . . . , p c ij,g(26)
div.p: where p c ij,l , l = 0, 1, . . . , g is computed by
div.formula: p c ij,l = t k=1 λ k p k ij,l . (27
div.p: For each alternative A i , the overall assessment value Z i is obtained using the HFLOWA operator
div.formula: Z i = HFLOWA r c i1 , . . . , r c im = HFLOWA P c i1 , . . . , P c im = p i,0 , . . . , p i,g(28)
div.p: where p i,l , l = 0, 1, . . . , g is computed by
div.formula: p i,l = m j=1 w j p c iσ (j),l(29)
div.p: and {σ (1), . . . , σ (m)} is a permutation of {1, 2, . . . , m} such that r c iσ (j) is the jth largest element in the ith row. If we choose to use a nondecreasing fuzzy quantifier Q to calculate the weights, then the weight w j is given by [54] The overall assessment values Z i , i = 1, 2, . . . , n need to be compared using their mean and variance values. Ranking the alternatives according to the value of Z i , i = 1, 2, . . . , n. The best alternatives are the ones with a maximum Z i .

Based on the consensus process in Section IV-B and the selection process in this section, a sequential decision framework for MAGDM problems with hesitant fuzzy linguistic information is summarized in Fig. 2.

div.head: VI. APPLICATION EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, we give two simulated applications of the proposed approach. The first example is a personnel evaluation and selection problem which aims to illustrate the decision framework in Fig. 2. The second example is used to make a comparative analysis.

div.head: A. Application to Personnel Selection
div.p: Due to the increasing competition in the world market, more and more modern organizations have realized the important role of choosing the right personnel for their sustainable development. Personnel selection has attracted intensive attention and has been an important topic for organizations. In the following, a personnel evaluation and selection problem for a manufacturing company is considered [4]. The manufacturing company wishes to recruit a sales manager for a vacant position. After preelimination, a set of four candidates A = {A 1 , A 2 , A 3 , A 4 } have been designated for further evaluation. To perform the evaluation, a decision group made up of four experts related to human resources management = {e 1 , e 2 , e 3 , e 4 } was established. After discussion, six attributes were identified to further measure the performance of each candidate. The attributes considered were oral communication skills (C 1 ), past experience (C 2 ), general aptitude (C 3 ), willingness (C 4 ), self-confidence (C 5 ), and first impression (C 6 ). Each expert provided their opinion using HFLTSs based on the following linguistic term set: S = {s 0 = very poor, s 1 = poor, s 2 = slightly poor s 3 = fair, s 4 = slightly good, s 5 = good s 6 = very good}.
The four hesitant fuzzy linguistic decision matrices are given in Tables I-IV.
According to the methodology described in the previous section, the following stages are applied.

div.head: 1) Stage 1 (Consensus Process):
div.p: To compute the similarity matrix, all HFLTSs in each decision matrix are first transformed into corresponding possibility distributions. For example, the possibility distribution corresponds r 3 11 = {s 2 , s 3 , s 4 } is (0, 0, 1/3, 1/3, 1/3, 0, 0).
The similarity matrices are given in Appendix B of the supplementary material.

The consensus matrix is In this example, the global consensus level is γ = 0.80. Since cd < γ, this indicates that there is no consensus amongst the experts and a feedback mechanism needs to be conducted. According to the proposed method in Section IV-B, the following rules are obtained. a) IR for Alternatives:
div.formula: ALT = {A i ∈ X|ca i < 0.8} = {A 1 , A 3 }.
div.p: That is, there are some elements in the first row and the third row of the decision matrix that need to be renewed. b) IR for Attributes of the Identified Alternatives: For alternative A 1 , we have
For alternative A 3 , we have

Then, all the positions over which the assessments should change are given by In a similar way, we have All the elements that need to be reconsidered are listed in the first column of Table V. DRs are used to guide the experts when changing their preferences. According to ( 24) and ( 25), the possibility distributions for r c ij and r k ij , (i, j) ∈ Pos are in Table V.

According to the DRs, suppose the experts provided the following new preferences: 2) Stage 2 (Aggregation Process): Following the indirect GDM approach, the individual hesitant fuzzy linguistic decision matrices R 1 -R 4 are aggregated to a group hesitant fuzzy linguistic decision matrix R c using the HFLWA operator. Without a loss of generality, all experts are assumed to have equal weight. Each element of R c is represented by its possibility distribution and these are shown in Appendix B of the supplementary material.

div.head: ) Stage 3 (Exploitation Process):
div.p: To rank the alternatives, the overall assessment value, Z i , for each alternative should be computed using the HFLOWA operator. The linguistic quantifier "most" is used to determine the associated weights for the HFLOWA operator. In this way, the weight vector is determined as W = (0, 0.067, 0.333, 0.333, 0.267, 0).
To calculate Z i , we have from ( 28) and ( 29) Furthermore, we have
div.formula: Z 1 = HFLOWA r c 11 ,
div.p: Therefore, the ranking of the alternatives is
div.formula: A 2 A 3 A 4 A 1 .
div.p: Alternative A 2 was considered as the best candidate for the sales manager position for the manufacturing company.

It should be noted that in some applications, it may be appropriate to transform the mean value of a possible distribution to a linguistic two-tuple to make the results more understandable. Taking as an example E(Z 1 ), under the assumption of using the two-tuple linguistic model, the twotuple that expresses the equivalent information is (s 4 , -0.3). Therefore, A 1 is qualified to obtain a grade between "fair" and "slightly good."

div.head: B. Example for Comparison
div.p: Consider the example in [28]. Suppose that the manager of a company wants to select a material supplier to purchase some key components of a new product. After preliminary screening, four candidates VI.

As we are dealing with only one expert (the manager), it is a special case of GDM. According to the framework in Fig. 2, the consensus process and aggregation process are therefore unnecessary. Therefore, we can directly utilize the exploitation process. First, all the elements in R are transformed into corresponding possibility distributions P 11 = (0, 0, 0, 1/3, 1/3, 1/3, 0) P 12 = (0, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0) P 13 = (0, 0, 0, 0, 1/3, 1/3, 1/3) P 14 = (0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1/2, 1/2) P 21 = (0, 0, 0, 0, 1/3, 1/3, 1/3) P 22 = (0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1/2, 1/2) P 23 = (0, 0, 0, 1/2, 1/2, 0, 0) P 24 = (0, 0, 1/2, 1/2, 0, 0, 0) P 31 = (0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1/2, 1/2) P 32 = (0, 0, 1/2, 1/2, 0, 0, 0) P 33 = (0, 0, 0, 0, 1/2, 1/2, 0) P 34 = (0, 0, 0, 0, 1/3, 1/3, 1/3) P 41 = (0, 0, 0, 1/2, 1/2, 0, 0) P 42 = (0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1/2, 1/2) P 43 = (0, 0, 0, 0, 1/2, 1/2, 0)
Since the weights of the criteria are known, we can use the HFLWA operator to calculate the overall assessment value. The obtained results represented by possibility distribution are as follows:
To compare these values, we use the expected value and get
The ranking of the alternatives is
div.formula: A 3 A 1 A 2 A 4 .
div.p: Therefore, the best alternative of this decision problem is A 3 . If we use the fuzzy envelope-based approach [28], the HFLTSs are first transformed to fuzzy envelopes and then a fuzzy TOPSIS method is carried out to rank the alternatives. The ranking of the alternatives [28] is
div.formula: A 3 A 1 A 2 A 4
div.p: which is exactly the same with the proposed approach described above. This result shows the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed approach.

div.head: VII. DISCUSSION
div.p: In this section, based on the results of the examples, we discuss the advantages and disadvantages of the proposed approach and the possible extensions of the proposed model.

The concept of possibility distribution provides a fundamental vehicle to deal with HFLTSs. In a more general manner, a possibility distribution can be seen as a fuzzy restriction [58]. The normalized distribution facilitates the understanding and computation and is therefore adopted. It presents a new way to deal with HFLTSs. As for any fuzzy multi-attribute decision making (MADM) method, one fundamental process is how to deal with the given fuzzy information. The possibility distribution-based approach provides a different perspective to explain the hesitate fuzzy linguistic information. The mean and variance of possibility distributions are defined to compare two HFLTSs. This comparison method has the advantage of high distinguishability as shown in the examples. It provides an alternative way to comparison methods for HFLTSs in [40], [47], and [48]. As mentioned in Section I, some existing approaches require the number of values of two HFLTSs has to be extended to the same or need to calculate the envelope with several fuzzy membership functions [28], [63]. These approaches may cause information loss or distortion.

The presented aggregation operators HFLWA and HFLOWA generalize the crisp WA-like and OWA-like aggregation operators. In Section VI, both aggregation operators have been used in the exploitation process. In the WA-like HFLWA operator, weighting vectors are chosen in such a way that each weight reflects the reliability of the information sources. If we know the weights of criteria, it is recommended to use the HFLWA operators. Otherwise, the HFLOWA operator can be used. In the way of this paper, some other aggregation operators such as the Bonferroni mean and the generalized OWA can be generalized to deal with hesitant fuzzy linguistic information [55], [56]. Some operators have already been extended to hesitant situations (see [49], [51], [60], [62], amongst others). It was found that the extended aggregation operators possess the same properties as the original crisp aggregation operators. Theoretically, for any preference structure, crisp operators such as WA and OWA can be applied to the new structure.

The use of consensus reaching process plays a key role in GDM. Because there is no similar study that develops the consensus reaching process for HFLTSs, a direct comparative study is not possible. In our proposed feedback mechanism, we do not use proximity measures but build the advice production directly on the consensus measures developed in Section IV-A. It is worth noting that proximity measures are used only to generate the advice rules. If we can obtain the advice rules directly, we can simplify the consensus process. We first find the position at which the experts need to modify their preferences, and then we find which expert needs to change their preferences. This strategy is more acceptable in the sense that each expert may be asked to make some changes in the consensus process and no one is considered an authority.

Though the presented consensus process has served its purpose. It can be further improved in some aspects. In real-world applications, both number or percent of experts and positions can be adaptively determined in each round. An adaptive consensus process is a process which adapts its behavior to the agreement achieved in each round [31]. Let ne be the number or percent of experts in each EXPS ij that need to change their preferences and np be the number or percent of positions in Pos. Then a simple strategy can be designed. The global consensus level cd is first classified into several grades such as very low, low, and medium. Then ne and np are decided according to the current grade. For example, if the grade is very low, then we may take ne = np = 75% and if the grade is low, then we may take ne = np = 50%. Using the adaptive strategy increases the convergence toward the consensus and reduces the number of rounds needed to reach it.

The framework model described in Fig. 2 has some practical implications. The decision making takes three basic stages into account: the consensus process, the aggregation process, and the exploitation process. It provides a complete procedure handling the case where a group of experts want to achieve concordance among the alternatives. The selection process can be utilized either separately or by combining with the consensus process. Based on the consensus process, other known classical MADM methods such as TOPSIS can be integrated into the framework model.

A drawback of the proposed approach is that the mean computation for possible distribution depends on the numerical scale of the linguistic terms. If the linguistic term set S is uniformly and symmetrically distributed, it is easy to get the numerical scale. Otherwise it has proved difficult. Fortunately, this problem may be solved according to the nature of the problem itself.

div.head: VIII. CONCLUSION
div.p: Multiple attribute decision making has been found to be a useful tool in solving management problems in organizations. To deal with an MAGDM with hesitant fuzzy linguistic information, we proposed a decision model which incorporated a consensus process and a selection process. We have also given simulated examples to illustrate the use of the proposed approach. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows.

1) The concept of possibility distributions for HFLTS has been defined. It is a natural explanation for the linguistic terms in an HFLTS since HFLTS is originally presented to manage the possible linguistic values. 2) By considering the possibility distributions corresponding to the hesitant fuzzy linguistic information, we have presented an HFLWA operator and an HFLOWA operator. We have also discussed the desirable properties for these operators. 3) We have presented a consensus process to assist experts in achieving a predefined consensus level. This consensus process is based on Herrera-Viedma et al.'s method [22]. The proposed consensus process simplifies the existing methods by reducing the proximity measures and adapting different feedback strategies. 4) We have provided a selection process to rank the alternatives which utilizes the HFLWA operator and the HFLOWA operator and can be implemented and understood by choosing the aggregation operator weights. In future work, the developed theoretical structure could be extended to unbalanced linguistic scales and multigranular linguistic settings. Another interesting direction is to analyze the hesitant fuzzy linguistic information in preference relations.

Zhibin Wu (M'13) received the Ph.D. degree in management science and engineering from Sichuan University, Chengdu, China, in 2012.

He is currently an Associate Professor with the Business School, Sichuan University. His current research interests include group decision making, soft computing, aggregation operators, multicriteria decision analysis and applications, and decision sup-
